articles.author: Matt Williams
articles.summary:
Africa is home to 7 out of 10 of the world's fastest-growing economies. It's
population is also the "youngest" in the world, with 50% of the population
being 19 years old or younger. And amongst these young people are scores of
innovators and entrepreneurs who are looking to bring homegrown innovation to
their continent and […]
articles.title: Africa’s First Mission to the Moon Announced (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
Autosomal dominant vitreoretinochoroidopathy and its relationship with gene
BEST1 have been added to Genetics Home Reference. Web links to MedlinePlus,
NIH publications, patient support web sites, Genetic Testing Registry,
ClinicalTrials.gov, PubMed, and OMIM are included.
articles.title: autosomal dominant vitreoretinochoroidopathy (US NLM)

articles.summary:
BILLINGS, Mont. (AP) -- Conservation groups have sued the government to force
federal officials to undertake the first broad environmental review of the
government's coal-leasing program in decades....
articles.title: Conservationists sue over federal coal program (The Arizona Republic)

articles.author: newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz
articles.summary:
The elderly Australian man presumed dead after falling 25m into rough seas
from a cruise ship was missing for more than four hours before his
disappearance was reported.The 84-year-old's fall into the Tasman Sea from the
Sun Princess...
articles.title: Cruise ship fall: Lost man not reported for four hours (co.nz)

articles.summary:
Polyether polyols, derivatives and combinations thereof are converted to
olefins under reductive or non-reductive dehydroxylation conditions, in the
presence of a halogen-based catalyst. Derivatives include polyether polyols
incorporated in polyurethanes. The process includes gas pressure from 1 psig
(˜6.89 KPa) to 2000 psig (˜13.79 MPa), a temperature from 50° C....
articles.title: Dehydroxylation of polyether polyols and their derivatives using a halogen-based catalyst (Fresh Patents)

articles.summary:
Much of the United States may have been shivering over the past week or so,
with poor Buffalonians worried that their roofs might collapse under
staggering amounts of snow. But on the other side of the Earth, Australians
have had a far different experience. For Australia, it was the second warmest
October on record. (Globally, two separate reports place October as either the
warmest or in a tie for warmest.) That got me wondering what the wildfire
situation has been Down Under. So I fired
articles.title: Dramatic Growth of Australian Bushfire as Seen from Space (Discover Magazine)

articles.summary:
(BBC) - Burial workers in the Sierra Leonean city of Kenema have dumped bodies
in public in protest at non-payment of allowances for handling Ebola victims.
The workers, who went on strike over the issue, left 15 bodies abandoned at …
Read More
articles.title: Ebola Outbreak: Sierra Leone Workers Dump Bodies in Kenema (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
(_Baylor College of Medicine_) An international collaboration of scientists
including Baylor College of Medicine has completed the first genome sequence
of a myriapod, Strigamia maritima -- a member of a group venomous centipedes
that care for their eggs -- and uncovered new clues about their biological
evolution and unique absence of vision and circadian rhythm.
articles.title: International collaboration completes genome sequence of centipede (Eurekalert)

articles.summary:
Stephanie Green studies lionfish in The Bahamas. If you live in lionfish
territory in the Atlantic Ocean, the last thing you want to be is a small fish
with a long, skinny body, resting by yourself at night, near the bottom of the
seafloor.
articles.title: Lionfish analysis reveals most vulnerable prey as invasion continues (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
LONDON (Reuters) - An international team of more than 100 researchers has
mapped the genome of the centipede and found that, while it easily outpaces
humans on number of legs, it falls short when it comes to genes.
articles.title: One for every leg: scientists map centipede genome (reuters)

articles.summary:
Differences in breast size have a significant mental health impact in
adolescent girls, affecting self-esteem, emotional well-being, and social
functioning, reports the December issue of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery,
the official medical journal of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons.
articles.title: Study shows mental health impact of breast size differences in teens (Eurekalert)

changed since Louise Brown, the first test tube baby, was born in 1978. The
explosion of … Read More
articles.title: When Making Babies Goes High Tech: A Future Tense Event Recap (bioethicscom)

articles.author: Guardian: None Given
articles.summary:
Guardian: The World Bank will invest heavily in clean energy and only fund
coal projects in “circumstances of extreme need” because climate change will
undermine efforts to eliminate extreme poverty, says its President Jim Yong
Kim. Talking ahead of a U.N. climate summit in Peru next month, Kim said he
was alarmed by World Bank-commissioned research from the Potsdam Institute for
Climate Impact Research in Germany, which said that as a result of past
greenhouse gas emissions the world is condemned to unprecedented...
articles.title: World Bank to ditch coal for clean energy (climateark)
